author: sauliusgrigaitis
content:
So you would feel much safer if https://beaconstate.info/ claims that it serves Prysm checkpoints? You just confirmed how broken is this whole idea.

1. Buy a legit looking domain like beaconstate.info
2. Install Checkpointz and change it : a) so it claims that open source CLs serve  checkpoints, b) claims that EF is running the site. Now it's a legit source of truth that even core devs trust.
3. Serve fake snapshots.

author: potuz
content: No, I don't care nor trust any site that serves anything, But I would take it as a big warning if an EF controlled site used a closed source implementation of any client. That was my only objection

author: potuz
content: Not because of the dangers in the content served, but because of the implicit endorsement of the EF to a closed sourced implementation

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: Yea, some random website with the code found on the github made your team think that it's run by EF. That's the problem.

author: potuz
content: I'm not sure about the team, but it **made me** think it's run by the EF... perhaps I am more naive than the rest of the world, but I do expect that the number of people that would fall for that is higher than 1.

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: OK, so it just confirms that the solution to the problem is to just stop serving checkpoints via such websites and remove such functionality from  CL clients that allows loading checkpoints from websites.

author: potuz
content: I think you're conflating two separate issues here. I don't mind sites serving checkpoints. People can and will be tricked. Not because of this we should prevent all users to have access to something that would make their UX slightly better. We should strive at the very least to have some players that have high reputation in the community, to not be the ones tricking users: e.g. the EF posting false checkpoints would be something much worse than finding false checkpoints in 2600.com

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: I don't think I'm conflating two separate issues. I'm raising the root cause instead of trying to hide it. No checkpoint website no matter who runs it can be trusted, especially until withdrawals (who knows when it will be live and syncing from genesis is more secure until then). So the content on those websites doesn't even worth the discussion. Otherwise, blockchains will start to run at "some players that have high reputation in the community" servers ðŸ™‚

content: I can trust client devs (and the infrastructure they and I use) to sync from the correct genesis file, but not trust anyone ever to provide me a more recent checkpoint? That... makes very little sense?

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: I didn't say "anyone ever", I said websites.

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: For sure you can take snapshot from the beacon node you trust, but from a random website that looks like it's run by EF just because it has stock Checkpointz installed.

content: I think the point is that it doesn't have to be a random website? You can also use _my_ checkpointz endpoint for example (and you may still not trust me of course).

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: We just saw how easy is to trick a power user with a random website. Average joe is much worse.

author: pietjepuk
content:
Actually, I would say he was the typical paranoid power user in immediately asking questions because things didn't add up ("run by the EF?!" to paraphrase). Second, it was and still is in development afaik. The link already includes some more marking that indicates it's "just some dude's" checkpoint instance, i.e. not affiliated with the EF.

And the alternative to "random" websites would be "random" opaque URLs to REST-endpoints. Not sure that's any better.

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: I think you are just confirming the problem. I still don't see why average joe would not trust some legit domain or phished domain with stock Checkpointz that serves fake checkpoints.

author: pietjepuk
content: I really don't see where you are going with this. Are you saying trust is not needed at all?

author: sonic.1337
content:
That's my Checkpointz instance, I changed the name to make it clear that it is "very clearly untrustworthy". I never had the intention to make it look "official", I basically used the default design.
I don't like closed source, but <@777935002263617576> always communicated, that he wants to make Grandine open source, if possible. I hope this will be possible and that's why I'm testing the client.

I don't want this to sound like "Whataboutism" now, but we have much bigger security issues in my opinion. The `staking-deposit-cli` (<https://github.com/ethereum/staking-deposit-cli/releases/tag/v2.3.0>) is hosted on GitHub without signature. The `SHA256 Checksum` shown there is useless and gives users a false feeling of security. We are basically trusting `GitHub.com` and every person who has access to this account.

I would really prefer the `staking-deposit-cli` to be signed by multiple client teams maybe or at least the checksum to be posted at multiple locations. It should clearly be communicated that people need to check the authenticity  of the `staking-deposit-cli` by using multiple locations. (The same as checking the checkpoint by using multiple locations.)

There is already an open issue, but no progress. <https://github.com/ethereum/staking-deposit-cli/issues/119>

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: My point is that the real solution to the problem (after withdrawals) is to load checkpoints from the people you trust. This means no website can be involved.

author: pietjepuk
content: So how do you load a checkpoint from, say, me then?

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: I call you, you do the snapshot and I transfer it from you.

author: sonic.1337
content: From who you get the checkpoint is completely unimportant. It's important to check that your client is on the right chain, by cross checking it with *multiple people/locations you trust*.

author: pietjepuk
content: Or, and hear me out, you put my checkpointz url in, sync to it, and then call me to check your client is synced to the correct head

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: right, but we all here agree that "cross checking it with multiple people/locations you trust" and "call me to check your client is synced to the correct head" just doens't happen.

author: pietjepuk
content: so the alternative is... no one ever uses checkpoint sync because it's too user friendly?

author: pietjepuk
content: it's a quick way to get synced to head, to get a new client part of the network.. with the only alternative to that being the use of a centralized service, I'll take it any day of the week

author: sonic.1337
content:
Many people do install there staking setup by copy pasting a step by step guide. People would even use `rm -rf / --no-preserve-root` if the guide has this instructions.
I think we need to communicate it clearly, that everybody needs to cross check instructions, checkpoints and software.

author: sonic.1337
content: It's not really a technical problem.

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: The alternative is to run at least one beacon node in your circle. This both will help the network and will serve snapshots. This would make these checkpoint websites obsolete, clients would not need to support checkpoint syncing from urls so it will eliminate this attack vector.

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: Yes,  but this technical problem would not exists if there would not be such checkpoint websites and ability to load checkpoints from it.

author: pietjepuk
content: I don't see the difference between me providing snapshots to friends via file transfer/floppy disks/..., or me providing snapshots to friends via a website. With the latter being a _lot_ more convenient for all parties.

author: sonic.1337
content:
That's true. But my point is, that you always need to trust someone at some point. (Like downloading the client itself, the `staking-deposit-cli`, the creator of a guide.)
The only thing you really can do is never to trust a single person/source, only multiple (seemingly) trustworthy. It's very hard for an attacker to manipulate multiple independent locations at the same time.
